docs.lead_paragraph: Cardioverter defibrillators, which are implanted in some people with irregular heartbeats, are credited with saving untold lives. But there is a downside. When the devices sense that the heartbeat has become irregular, they send out jolts of electricity to restore the normal rhythm. And those jolts can be startling, even painful.

headline.main: Preparing the Heart for a Needed Jolt

docs.abstract: Researchers find way to make cardioverter defibrillators less uncomfortable (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Social psychology, the study of how the social environment shapes human behavior, is not an ivory tower science; it is a tool for helping to solve real world problems, like bigotry and violence. Dr. Elliot Aronson, a social psychologist and author, always preached this philosophy to his graduate students, but one day a phone call from a former student forced him to prove it. It was 1971 and Dr. Aronson was head of the social psychology department at the University of Texas. By then, the former student had become an assistant superintendent in the Austin schools, which were in crisis after desegregation. Riots had broken out among black, Hispanic and white students and the district asked Dr. Aronson to help.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/Elliot Aronson; No One Left to Hate: Averting Columbines

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Elliot Aronson, social psychologist and author, who has a teaching plan that forces students to work together and may help curb school violence; he sees root of problem as cliquish environment in many schools in which unpopular students are ostracized; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Social psychology, the study of how the social environment shapes human behavior, is not an ivory tower science; it is a tool for helping to solve real world problems, like bigotry and violence. Dr. Elliot Aronson, a social psychologist and author,...

docs.lead_paragraph: George Eliot's partner protected her from reviews. Isak Dinesen reduced the anxiety of exposure by ducking behind a pseudonym. The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Louise Gluck once said she felt ''anxiety'' before writing and ''dread'' upon publication. And recently, Judith Thurman, a National Book Award-winning biographer, told an audience of psychologists and psychoanalysts: ''The anxiety of authorship is one of the very few topics on which I feel I have the authority to speak without notes, research or preparation because there is not a nerve in my writer's body that isn't anxious most of the time.''

headline.main: Examining, and Easing, the Anxiety of Authorship

docs.abstract: Authors and psychoanalysts interested in women and creativity meet in Manhattan for conference on The Anxiety of Authorship: Examining and Overcoming Women's Inhibitions in Self-Expression; among leaders of conference are Lucy Grealy, Dr Elisabeth Young-Bruehl, Judith Thurman, Dr Jessica Benjamin and Anne Roiphe (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to fighting incipient heart disease in young people, just watching cholesterol levels is not enough. That is the reminder in a new study that looks at what lies behind the development of atherosclerosis, or artery hardening.

headline.main: In Youth, It's Not Just About Cholesterol

docs.abstract: New study find that young people with normal cholesterol show evidence of atherosclerosis that appears linked to factors like obesity, high blood pressure, smoking and diabetes (S)
docs.snippet: When it comes to fighting incipient heart disease in young people, just watching cholesterol levels is not enough.    That is the reminder in a new study that looks at what lies behind the development of atherosclerosis, or artery hardening.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Culture of Death: The Assault on Medical Ethics in America,'' by Wesley J. Smith, Encounter Books, $23.95. Death is a universal human experience that most of us only grudgingly glance at over a shoulder every so often.

headline.main: Harsh Words for Those Who Defy 'Do No Harm'

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews Wesley J Smith book Culture of Death: The Assault on Medical Ethics in America; book chastises what it sees as American medical system that allows doctors to withdraw care based on their evaluation of patients' likely quality of life; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ''Culture of Death: The Assault on Medical Ethics in America,'' by Wesley J. Smith, Encounter Books, $23.95.      Death is a universal human experience that most of us only grudgingly glance at over a shoulder every so often.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is not uncommon for seriously ill patients to ask their doctors to help them commit suicide. But while it is a wrenching situation, the doctors often go it alone, a new study reports. ''A professional code of silence regarding P.A.S. creates professional isolation,'' said the report in a recent issue of Archives of Internal Medicine, using the abbreviation for physician-assisted suicide.

headline.main: Answers for Doctors on Suicide Question

docs.abstract: New study finds that doctors who are asked by patients to help them commit suicide often decide to deal with problem by themselves, without sharing their situation with colleagues (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to spinach, parents can be pretty crafty about sneaking it into food, many a child has learned. But mom and dad cannot compare to what researchers at the University of Arkansas have in mind. They think that fast-food restaurants should begin substituting raw vitamin-rich spinach for lettuce in the estimated billions of sandwiches they sell each year.

headline.main: Like Some Spinach With Those Fries?

docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Arkansas think that fast-food restaurants should begin substituting raw vitamin-rich spinach for lettuce in sandwiches they serve (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just walking for at least an hour a week is now associated with less heart disease in women. And it does not even seem to matter how fast one moves, researchers reported last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association. ''Even if you do a little bit, you get a benefit,'' said the lead researcher, Dr. I-Min Lee, an epidemiologist at Harvard and at Brigham and Women's Hospital.

headline.main: Slow Lane Also Leads to Heart Health

docs.abstract: Researchers report that just walking for an hour a week can lessen a woman's chances of heart disease (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: People who do not meet the current standards of body beautiful -- with narrow waist, slim hips and trim thighs -- might enjoy knowing that this idealized form was not built to last, at least not for three or more decades beyond a woman's childbearing years. In fact, if people were manufactured products, one might justifiably accuse their producer of planned obsolescence. Ask almost anyone over 50 and you are likely to encounter complaints about aching backs, sore knees, tired legs, failing vision, fading hearing, waning strength and/or fragile bones.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on design problems of human body; commonplace complaints and symptoms of physical deterioration after 50 prompt three experts on aging to propose redesign of human body, inside and out, that could enhance its ability to last to age 100 without falling apart; experts are Dr Robert N Butler, Dr S Jay Olshansky and Dr Bruce A Carnes; drawing (M)
